item.title: Hundreds Missing After Chinese Cruise Ship Sinks on Yangtze
item.description: China’s official news agency said the sinking occurred Monday night in a storm and that as of Tuesday morning, only eight people had been rescued.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Bribery Inquiry Drawing Closer to FIFA’s President, Sepp Blatter
item.description: Law enforcement officials said that Jérôme Valcke, FIFA’s secretary general, is the person who prosecutors say made a 2008 bank transfer to a soccer official accused of taking a bribe.
item.category: Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football (CONCACAF)
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: Jérôme Valcke, right, the FIFA secretary general, shook hands with Sepp Blatter at last week's FIFA Congress.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Willy Wo-Lap Lam on ‘Chinese Politics in the Era of Xi Jinping’
item.description: Willy Wo-Lap Lam, a 62-year-old professor at Chinese University of Hong Kong. is the author of five books analyzing China’s top leaders since Zhao Ziyang.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, who has veered away from the “first among equals” approach in favor of the “big boss” model, according to the China scholar Willy Wo-Lap Lam.

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Weather Halts Solar Plane
item.description: A solar-powered plane trying to circle the globe without a drop of fuel made an unscheduled landing late Monday in Japan to wait out bad weather.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: 2 Die of MERS Virus
item.description: The two patients were being treated for respiratory ailments in a hospital last month when they had contact with the nation’s first MERS patient.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: European Leaders Assemble for Urgent Meeting on Greek Crisis
item.description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece is under mounting pressures from many sides, and European leaders hope to help his cash-starved country swiftly meet its financial obligations.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN, NIKI KITSANTONIS and JACK EWING
item.media:description: A Greek newspaper with Prime Minister Alex Tsipras on the cover last week.

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Scores Killed as Oil Tanker Crashes Into a Packed Bus Station
item.description: A runaway oil tanker truck exploded in a crowded bus station in Nigeria’s south, setting 12 buses ablaze and killing 69 people.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Teachers Union Members Damage Election Offices in Protest
item.description: Members of a radical Mexican teachers union broke into or blockaded electoral offices in Oaxaca State on Monday amid threats to block Sunday’s midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Iran’s Nuclear Stockpile Grows, Complicating Negotiations
item.description: Iran’s nuclear material has increased during talks with the United States, despite the Obama administration’s assertion that the program had been “frozen.”
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, left, with the Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, in Geneva on Saturday.

item.title: Americans and Turks Discuss ISIS Threat
item.description: Officials are discussing a joint effort to clear Islamic State fighters away from Turkey’s southern border.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Shiite militiamen clashed with members of the Islamic State in Fallujah, Iraq. Turkey wants to clear ISIS from its southern border.

item.title: Obama Plans to Nominate Roberta Jacobson to Be Ambassador to Mexico
item.description: Ms. Jacobson, a Mexico specialist who rose through the ranks of the State Department, has been at the center of Mr. Obama’s overhaul of American policy toward Cuba.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: American Woman Is Mauled to Death by a Lion
item.description: The 22-year-old woman died Monday after a lion jumped into her vehicle through an open window at a wildlife park on the outskirts of Johannesburg.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: African Countries Are Urged to Investigate Reports of Abuse by Peacekeepers
item.description: The United Nations’ top human rights official has urged African members to prosecute what he called longstanding abuse allegations by troops sent to keep the peace in the Central African Republic.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Ship With 457 People Reported Sunk in China’s Yangtze
item.description: China’s official news agency said the sinking occurred Monday night in a storm and that as of Tuesday morning, only eight people had been rescued.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Gazans’ Hopes for Rebuilding After War Give Way to Deeper Despair
item.description: Hamas quietly initiated new import fees in an effort to cover the salaries of some 40,000 employees, raising prices in already depressed markets.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunset through a destroyed building on the Gaza shore. Many ruined structures remain from the war with Israel last summer.

item.title: Four Militants Killed in Gun Battle With Indian Troops
item.description: Clashes in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir left four militant fighters dead, the Indian Army said.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Bangladesh Police Charge 41 With Murder Over Rana Plaza Collapse
item.description: More than 1,100 people were killed in the 2013 collapse of the building, which housed several clothing factories, in what is the garment industry’s worst disaster.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: The collapsed Rana Plaza building near Dhaka, Bangladesh, in 2013.

item.title: Buckfast Journal: English Abbey’s Caffeinated Wine Gains Popularity and Scrutiny
item.description: A favorite of young drinkers, especially in Scotland, the product has been blamed for contributing to crime, and lawmakers are considering bans unless its contents are changed.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Benedictine monks of Buckfast Abbey in southwestern England produce Buckfast Tonic Wine, an alcoholic drink with a jolt of caffeine. The drink's popularity has put the abbey and the surrounding area into the midst of a debate over who bears responsibility for alcohol abuse.

item.title: American Journalist Is Freed by Yemen’s Houthi Rebels
item.description: The release of the journalist, Casey L. Coombs, came the same day that a video of a Frenchwoman seized in Yemen three months ago surfaced online.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Paris Bridge’s Love Locks Are Taken Down
item.description: Weighing heavily on the famed Pont des Arts, the countless padlocks — their keys thrown into the Seine — are being removed from the bridge.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN
